title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.16.17-18 | 20-01-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: So this is the wonderful relationship that exists between Krishna and his pure devotees in the spiritual world. And even in the material world when Krishna incarnates, he comes down with his confidential associates and he demonstrates to us what is life like in the spiritual world.
segments.summary: This segment describes Maharaj Pariksit's rule, the devotion of the Pandavas, and Krishna's willingness to serve his devotees, highlighting the relationship between Krishna and his pure devotees.

segments.key_quote: So, actually each one of us have got a relationship with Krishna. And we are meant to actually revive that relationship, especially when we have this human form of body.
segments.summary: This segment discusses the importance of reviving our relationship with Krishna, the fundamental questions answered by the Vedas, and the unfavorable conditions of Kali Yuga.

themes: Symbolism of the bull and cow
Condition of the earth in Kali Yuga
segments.key_quote: The personality of religious principles, Dharma, was wandering about in the form of a bull, and he met, that is, Dharma, met the personality of earth in the form of a cow, who appeared to grieve like a mother who had lost her child.
segments.summary: This segment explains the symbolism of Dharma as a bull and Mother Earth as a cow, describing their condition at the beginning of Kali Yuga and the state of moral principles.

segments.key_quote: Among all the domestic animals, the most important are the bull and the cow.
segments.summary: This segment contrasts domestic and wild animals, emphasizing the importance of protecting the bull and cow in Vedic culture.

themes: Benefits of protecting bull and cow
Consequences of mistreating bull and cow
segments.key_quote: So, if the cow and bull are protected for the good of human society, then there is advancement of Brahmanical culture.
segments.summary: This segment explains the benefits of protecting the bull and cow for human society and the negative consequences of mistreating them, linking it to the decline of Brahmanical culture and spiritual values.
